column4: if you want the uuid, sudo blkid will tell you correct uuid of new swap, but can use /dev/sd**, too
sudo fdisk -l to list your partitioons, figure out /dev for swap ..
fstab has the same uuid of the blkid
then sth. went wrong, if you resize a partition, it's uuid will change
you did the resize from a live cd btw. least unmounted swap for resizing ?
I resized it by Gparted and I did unmounted it before resizing
that's strange, least if fstab is equal to blkid, you're fine, try a reboot, worst thing is a stuck > live-cd, comment swap, sys will start without swap for debugging then
can u check that plz http://pastebin.com/JCUf67ER
looks correct so far, strange if resising worked and you called no other function
you wouldn't have been able to resize, unles unmmounted, afterwards it'll have changed uuid at re-mount
see, resizing wasn't done then, there you go, got to do it again
the System monitor shows the old capacity and actually I do not know if the system works with new capacity or uses only the capacity shown in the system monitor
see, resizing wasn't done then, there you go, got to do it again
GParted show that the swap is at the new size
the swap size problem solved, I disabled it on the fstab then restarted then i make mkswap and everything is going ok now
